description: From Latin ūnanimus (“of one mind”), from ūnus (“one”) +‎ animus (“mind”). Displaced native Old English ānmōd (literally “one-minded”).

entries.meaning: Based on unanimity, assent or agreement.
examples: The debate went on for hours, but in the end the decision was unanimous.

entries.meaning: Sharing the same views or opinions, and being in harmony or accord.
examples: We were unanimous: the President had to go.
